importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the Gaza ceasefire deal was announced, marking a pivotal moment in international diplomacy and Trump’s foreign policy narrative.
The date of the article’s publication, indicating the current state of public opinion on Trump’s Gaza deal and economic policies.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which polling data was collected after the Gaza deal announcement, showing initial public reactions that did not translate into lasting approval.

keyTakeAways: Americans show little enthusiasm for Trump’s Gaza ceasefire deal, despite its international visibility.
Trump's overall approval rating has dropped to a second-term low, with 61% disapproving in one poll.
Public disapproval of Trump's economic policies — particularly inflation and cost of living — has reached a new low, with 62% disapproving of his handling of inflation.
Americans are increasingly pessimistic about the economy, with only 32% expecting economic improvement and 31% expecting wage growth over the next year.
The percentage of employed Americans not worried about job loss has declined to 52%, indicating growing economic anxiety.
Foreign policy issues, including the Gaza deal, are low on Americans' priorities — only 4% ranked international events as the top issue facing the country.
The public believes Trump has not focused enough on lowering prices, underscoring economic concerns over foreign policy achievements.
The Gaza deal appears fragile, with Vice President JD Vance traveling to Israel to assess its stability, suggesting ongoing regional tensions.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former U.S. President and current political figure
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is central to the article as the subject of public opinion on his Gaza ceasefire deal and domestic economic policies.

namedEntities.name: Gaza ceasefire deal
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A proposed agreement between Israel and Hamas to end hostilities in Gaza
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The deal is presented as a major foreign policy event, yet it fails to gain significant domestic public support or political traction.

namedEntities.name: Vice President JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Trump’s Vice President, involved in diplomatic outreach
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vance is leading a delegation to Israel to assess the stability of the Gaza ceasefire deal, indicating its precarious nature.

namedEntities.name: AP-NORC poll
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The AP-NORC poll shows Trump’s approval rating on Gaza increased slightly but remains balanced with disapproval, highlighting public ambivalence.

namedEntities.name: CNBC poll
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CNBC poll reveals Trump’s continued disapproval on both Gaza and the economy, with the economy being a stronger point of criticism.

namedEntities.name: Biden administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Biden administration’s earlier Gaza ceasefire deal (in January 2025) is referenced as a precedent for how quickly such agreements can fail, reinforcing skepticism about the current deal.

namedEntities.name: inflation
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A measure of rising prices in the economy
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Inflation is a key economic concern, with public disapproval of Trump’s handling of it reaching a record low.

namedEntities.name: cost of living
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A general indicator of economic hardship for households
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Americans express dissatisfaction with the cost of living under Trump’s policies, contributing to broader economic disapproval.

namedEntities.name: CBS News-YouGov poll
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This poll shows that international events are low on the public’s priority list, reinforcing the idea that domestic economic issues dominate public concern.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Despite a high-profile Gaza ceasefire deal brokered by President Donald Trump, American public opinion shows little enthusiasm for the agreement, with disapproval rates remaining high. Polling data from AP-NORC and CNBC indicate that Trump’s approval on the Gaza issue only marginally improved — from 37% to 47% — while overall approval dipped to a second-term low, with 61% disapproving. More significantly, public dissatisfaction with Trump’s economic management, especially inflation and the cost of living, has reached new lows, with 62% disapproving of his handling of inflation. Americans are also increasingly pessimistic about the economy, with declining confidence in economic improvement and wage growth. The article concludes that the public’s focus remains firmly on domestic economic issues, not foreign policy achievements, and that the fragile nature of the Gaza deal may not translate into political gains for Trump, especially in the face of persistent economic anxiety.
title: Americans shrug at Trump’s Gaza deal, as economic fears reign
